unnormalised: Okay, let’s be real. Fintech. Sounds fancy, right? Like some futuristic robot is managing your money while you sip chai. The truth is, it's mostly apps trying to get you to invest in things you barely understand. I mean, who actually *gets* cryptocurrency? I still think Bitcoin is something you dig for in your backyard. #OldSchool

unnormalised: But hey, I’m a millennial, and FOMO is practically in my blood. So, I downloaded a bunch of these fintech apps. One promised me 20% returns in just 3 months! It even had a fancy name, "WealthWizards." Turns out, the only wizardry involved was making my money disappear faster than you can say "demonetization." Lost ₹5000 in the first week. #NotAWealthWizardAnymore

unnormalised: Then there's the whole UPI payment scene. Love it, truly. Makes splitting the bill for samosas a breeze. But also, makes it way too easy to impulse-buy that random gadget on Amazon at 2:00 AM. My bank statement now looks like a love letter to Jeff Bezos. Thanks, Fintech! My wallet weeps.

unnormalised: But hey, I’m not totally hating on fintech. Some of these apps are actually quite useful. I use "BudgetBuddy" to track my expenses (mostly samosas, let's be honest). It sends me alerts when I'm about to overspend, which is usually every Tuesday. It also gave me an "A+" rating on saving. Must be a bug.

unnormalised: So, yeah, fintech is a mixed bag. It’s confusing, sometimes frustrating, and definitely capable of emptying your wallet faster than a street magician. But it also has the potential to make investing more accessible and managing your money slightly less painful. Just remember to do your research, avoid meme coins, and maybe consult a real-life financial advisor before betting your entire savings on "the next big thing". And always, always, always, double-check the OTP. Last time I didn’t, I ended up ordering 3 life-size cardboard cutouts of Shah Rukh Khan. Don't ask.
